unnormalised: Okay, so someone's asking about robotics in India? Cool topic! It's not exactly booming like, say, IT was in the 90s, but things are definitely picking up, especially with the "Make in India" initiative and all that. You see a lot of buzz around drone tech these days; agriculture and surveillance are big areas. DRDO's been doing a fair bit of robotics research for ages, mainly for defense purposes obviously.

unnormalised: Now, what's interesting is that smaller companies are also getting into the game. You see start-ups focused on things like automated cleaning robots for hospitals (very useful in these COVID times, no?) and even some dabbling in AI-powered robotics for manufacturing. Think of it this way: if you want a robot to sort parcels at Flipkart or Amazon, well, someone's gotta build it! And that "someone" could well be based in Bangalore or Pune.

unnormalised: The problem, as I see it, is still the cost factor. A decent industrial robot arm can easily set you back Rs. 20,00,000 – that's 20 lakh rupees! – and smaller businesses often can't afford that kind of initial investment. Plus, there's the whole issue of skilled labour to maintain and program these robots. We need more vocational training institutes to churn out engineers who can handle the complexities of robotics. IITs are great, but they are not enough.
